author: InfiniteValueptr
body:
The sectors that Corsair competes in and gets the vast majority of its revenue from are low-margin, commoditised products like memory and PSUs where everyone just rebrands Micron/Samsung/Superflower products. The only small advantage they have here is the brand, sustained by massive marketing spend. All of the acquisitions they've done are tiny and don't shift the needle on the bottom line. Elgato is probably the best business they have but that's tiny.  
Look through the financial statements going through history, and you'll notice that historic gross margins have stayed around 20%,and net income margins float around 0%. In 2020, net income margins were 6.1%. All of that increase (and more) can be attributed to the  700bp increase in gross margin. They have no operating leverage whatsoever.   
The key to this investment is whether that increase sticks around - not the PE firm, or meme potential, or growth of the wider gaming industry. If all of those go right, but gross margins go back to historic means, CRSR WILL NOT PRINT FCF.  
My view of the gaming market is that the past year has been a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for component makers like CRSR. The demand was so high that they could gouge prices and increase margins, but that's not going to stick around forever. I haven't seen a compelling argument for gross margins continuing to stay where they are.  
Arguments like Elgato having higher margins, or debt all being paid off in the future simply don't have big enough impacts to alter the fact that gross margin is the linchpin.

author: richardswingin
body:
Nvidia doesnt make their chips for their high end graphics cards. Micron does. 

Nvidia is a solid company from a product standpoint. I just built a gaming computer and used the highest end parts available for gaming. I use a nvidia rtx3090 and intel i910900k for a cpu.

As someone who is in this market as a consumer i feel safe speaking on it. Nvidia is awesome. But right now AMD is about to sweep the whole market.

AMD not only has very comparable graphics cards at a better price point but they also make their own cpus. 

AMD at the moment is gaining major ground. Their flagship cpus are THE BEST for workstations. Point blank. No comparisson. Their multi core cpu like the 5950x is actually as good as intels i910900k processor for gaming if not just a cunt hair better...plus it blows intel out of the water for multicore uses but at 2x the price. I used intels 10900k in my gaming build as it is neck and neck for the best cpu for gaming for half the cost. I have no use for the amd 5950x because i dont do content creation or stream. If i did i hands down wouldvw went for the 5950x. 

AMD is the play. Not nvidia.

author: CareerLow
body:
Ok, ready to start sharing some more of the data set I built for Russell Reconstitution Trade Theories. Looking for feedback before some of this goes out in the YEET tonight. Will make separate comment for each theory with explanation behind it. 

Starting with Large Caps, but can post Small Cap follow up if mods and everyone cool with it?

One rule applies to all theories- Stocks are weighted by FAMC (Float Adj. MC) which is hard to find so did rough estimate myself. More confident in my math after I saw Goldman had similar top 10. Not precise, but should be relatively close. 

Large Cap Buying Pressure: Stocks being added to Russell 1K for the first time will experience more buying pressure if they are weighted near the top. (Jeffries report in parenthesis)  
  
BX- RK1 (#2 in Buying Pressure by $)  
SNOW- RK1 (#1 in Buying Pressure by $)  
NXPI- RK1 (#4 in Buying Pressure by $)  
DASH- RK1 (#5 in Buying Pressure by $) - can't wait to short this fucker post rebalance, next ER feels right for redemption  
PLTR- RK1 (#3 in Buying Pressure by $)  
DKNG- RK1 (#6 in Buying Pressure by $)  
WIX- RK1 (#8 in Buying Pressure by $)

author: TheMadBeaker
body:
The global markets can't get enough chips right now. Lead times are crazy, and most fabs are \*just\* starting to raise prices, which we should see some really great Q2/Q3 profits. Many have committed billions to more fabs, but those will be years before they come online.

There is never going to be a decline in chip demand, they keep shoving more and more in everything.

Some stocks I bought early March: I'm up over 40% on NVDA, 23% on AMAT, 17% on NXPI, and 17% on UMC, 13% on TXN.

**\*Not stock advice\***

author: jokull1234
body:
Look at the top 10 qqq weighted companies from 1999-2001 compared to the top 10 today. The only glaringly overvalued one today is Tesla (and they still have huge revenues) 

Meanwhile the companies in 2000 include Cisco (probably more overvalued back then than Tesla is today), world com (lol), dell, Ericsson, and oracle. You can’t say with a straight face that the companies back then are anywhere close to as high quality as the top 10 today.

author: Foamy-Bot
body:
Super late reply, but think about McDonald's man. Just because making burgers is easy, people will still choose to buy McDonald's. 

Or think Starbucks for coffee or those no name factories that stay in business making those disgusting vending machine sandwiches. We as humans are real fucking lazy, impressively lazy. So while it may be easy to grow weed, and look up a few YouTube videos to do it. Humans are lazy people. 

Like I see it all the time, people want a amigurumi Plush, they could just google how to crochet, but they'll pay $100 for some person on etsy to make it. People want to make a website? Learning to program is easy but people would rather pay someone else to build it for them. It's all about that lazy factor. 

so I think we're looking for maybe the next couple years to see a boom, but no one here is an oracle. I have this stock and growgen corp as a pick and shovel strat.

If it all turns out to be crap somehow, and not budge by the time I die, or worse yet, all go bankrupt tomorrow. I guess I'm an idiot for making both those stocks, combined, 30% of my portfolio. But I still have AT&T, sbux, Apple, and Crown castle on the drip. 

We all make our beds in the market, and there's gotta be winners and losers.

author: Sir_Jimbo2222
body:
Yeah no shit the business model isn't niche the product/market they operate in is (i.e. niche market in the title).  Its biggest competitors are Blackline, Trintech,  and Oracle but none of them operate a platform for financial reporting processes (if they even have one) like Workiva.

A lot of SaaS companies focus their product around the financial close process (i.e. Oracle, SAP, Blackline) but Workiva operates in the Financial Reporting aspect which is completely different (i.e. it comes after the close process) and there is a lot of room for growth here.  In my post I even talked about how they sync their product with SAP platform to even further automate the financial reporting process.  Hell my company abandoned Blackline all together for Workiva cause it offers more.

You can cherrypick anything in an argument to try and make me sound dumb or misinformed but if you read my post you'll see what i'm talking about.  I've been in the space for 5 years now and seen roughly 20-25 different platforms used for accounting/financial close - none of them are like Workiva.

author: zeek0us
body:
The reason it hasn't been done before is because nobody thought it up/implemented it.  Or else it required the level of digital connectivity we only recently achieved to be realistic.  Or required too much effort from developers to get involved that it wasn't worth it.  In any case, that's a whole other discussion.  

But I find "if it's such a good idea why hasn't someone thought of it?" to be a weak argument -- it's true of just about every big thing before it becomes such.  Things catch on when they do because they do, often for a variety of connected reasons born of circumstance and chance.  It's enough to be a good idea, it doesn't have to be completely new -- execution matters.

I think the NFT thing is just a piece of the puzzle.  Easier to plug into than a proprietary Oracle DB or whatever.  It exists on its own and you just have to use it, not design/build/maintain it since it does that on its own.  In and of itself that's a huge benefit.  Not so much "necessary" as an obvious, effective solution to a problem of the business model -- namely, "how do we keep track of who owns what, and with which type of ownership status?"  But I'll admit I'm going beyond my depth in getting into the details -- I have to stop at being able to see how it could work, and can't walk through an airtight case that it would.

Anyway, Gamestop would add value as a gatekeeper/broker/middleman.  Business model as old as time.  Users go to Gamestop as the entry point to their gaming lives -- managing hardware/content.  Developers go to Gamestop to manage distribution.  Just because both parties *can* do it another way doesn't mean a central broker that makes things easier won't have value.  If the goal is for Gamestop to be the facilitator of all manner of gaming-related transactions (and they pull it off), that's an incredibly valuable position to be in.

Listen, I'm not saying it's a slam dunk by any means.  Just that I can see the path forward and how it might work out, in particular how going in some of these new directions could be lucrative.  Gaming is huge, and the infrastructure around it will need to evolve with the times.  Anyone who is successful at getting a piece of that pie will do very, very well.
